notes:
1. Importance

A Free-Body Diagram (FBD) is the most important tool in mechanics. It is a sketch of the body of interest, isolated from its surroundings (hence "free"), showing all the external forces and moments acting on it.

2. Steps to Draw an FBD

  1. Isolate the Body: Draw the outline of the body. Remove all supports and contacting bodies.
  2. Apply Active Forces: Draw vectors for all known external loads (gravity/weight, applied pushes/pulls). Weight acts through the center of gravity.
  3. Apply Reactive Forces: Replace supports and contacts with the appropriate reaction forces. (e.g., a cable becomes a tension force, a floor becomes a normal force and friction force).
  4. Label and Dimension: Add magnitudes, directions/angles, and relevant dimensions. Define a coordinate system (x, y).

3. Common Mistakes

  • Including internal forces (forces that parts of the body exert on each other).
  • Including forces exerted *by* the body on the surroundings (Newton's 3rd Law). Only forces *on* the body belong on the FBD.
  • Forgetting weight.
  • Incorrect support reactions (e.g., adding a moment at a pin support).

solvedExamples.question: In a free-body diagram of a ladder leaning against a frictionless wall, the force exerted by the wall on the ladder is represented as:

options.text: A force parallel to the ladder
Both a horizontal and vertical force

solvedExamples.explanation: A frictionless surface can only exert a normal force (perpendicular to the surface). Since the wall is vertical, the normal force is horizontal.

solvedExamples.question: Which forces should NOT be included in a free-body diagram of a specific body?

options.text: Forces exerted BY the body on other objects

solvedExamples.explanation: An FBD shows forces acting *on* the body. Forces exerted *by* the body are relevant to the FBDs of the *other* objects, not the body itself, according to Newton's 3rd Law.
